WHAT DID EARLY CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. D. R. McRea
Address: Applebury East
Birthplace: Ontario

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1927
Where did you set up housekeeping? Applebury
Where had you been living before that? Ontario
For how many people did you prepare meals? 3
How far was it to your nearest store? 7 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store?
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, oatmeal, sugar, tea, coffee, syrup, baking soda, baking powder, soda biscuits, spices

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?
Pine, Bassett or Quaker
In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lbs. or 100 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 2.00
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? Yes, how far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 75¢
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes, Whole wheat? Yes, Farina?
Rye?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it?
1. **RECENT HISTORY**

   That year did you start school? In Eastern Canada? ... P.A.Y.

   How did you get to school? By foot? ... Yes.

   Have you been living here before that? ... No.

   For how many pupils did you prepare meals? ... 3.

   How far was it to your nearest store? ... 2 miles.

   How often could a visit be made to the store? ... Weekly.

   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? ... Flour, oatmeal, sugar, tea, apple cider, baking soda, making powder, soda flour, vinegar, spices.

2. **FOOD COSTS**

   This brand of milk flour did you use in Eastern Canada? ... Yes.

   Price, Retail ... $1.00

   In that time did you buy 100 pounds of milk flour? ... Yes.

   How much did you pay per hundred pounds of milk flour? ... $1.00

   Whole wheat flour? ... Yes.

   Was flour rolled locally? ... Yes.

   For how much? ... $1.00

   Was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ... $1.00

   Other grain products did you use? ... Corn meal.

   Did you grind your own flour for porridge? ... No.

   How did you grind it? ... By hand.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy this sugar? 10 lbs or 1 cut.
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 75¢.
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Rogers.
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lbs or 20 lbs.
At what price? 75¢ per 10 lb. bail.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?
Butter? Made it.
Eggs? Bought them.
What was the price of butter? 25¢.
Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.
Did you make butter? Yes.
Cheese? No.
What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years?
Pork in summer & beef in winter.
How did you get fresh meat? Butchered our own or got some from the butcher shop in town.
How often did you get fresh meat? All winter.
How did you preserve meat? Freeze it in winter or put what was left in brine for summer.
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.
If so what year was it organized?
Did you use game? Not much.
What kinds?
For how long?
What part did fish play in the family diet? Got fresh fish in the winter.
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Sometimes white fish or mullets.
Kinds?

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased. (Give dates where possible).

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Winter - breakfast - oatmeal porridge, eggs or cold meat, toast or whole bread, coffee, tea or coffee
Dinner - roast beef or pork, potatoes, vegetable, bread or butter, pie or pudding
Supper - meat, pickles, potatoes, bread & butter, cake and cookie
Steamed fruit

Summer meals were much the same.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No.

19. Have you ever refused to eat meat? Living on one acre.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Coal or wood stoves were used with an occasional coal oil or gasoline stove.

Bread is made from quick rising yeast.

Very little meat is home cured and salt canned.

More canned vegetables are used.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).
